div.p:
A BRIEFE RELATION Of certain ≈øpeciall and mo≈øt materiall pa≈ø≈øages, and ≈øpeeches in the Starre-Chamber, occa≈øioned and delivered Iune the 1 ‚Ä¢
th. 1637. at the cen≈øure of tho≈øe three worthy Gentlemen, Dr. BASTWICKE, Mr. BVRTON and Mr. PRYNNE, as it hath beene truely and faithfully gathered from their owne mouthes by one pre≈øent at the ≈øayd Cen≈øure.
Printed in the Yeere 1637.

div.head: A Briefe Relation of certain ≈øpeciall and mo≈øt materiall pa≈ø≈øages, and ≈øpeeches in the Starre-Chamber, occa≈øioned and delivered Iune the 14th. 1637. at the cen≈øure of tho≈øe three worthy Gentlemen, Dr. BASTWICKE, Mr. BVRTON and Mr. PRYNNE, as it hath beene truely and faithfully gathered from their owne mouthes by one pre≈øent at the ≈øayd Cen≈øure.
div.p: BEtweene eight and nine a clocke in the morning (the 14. of Iune) the Lords being ≈øett in their places in the ≈øaid Court of Starre-chamber, and ca≈øting their eyes upon the Pri≈øoners, then at the Barr, Sr. Iohn Finch (chiefe Iu≈øtice of the Common Pleas) began to ≈øpeake after this maner.

sp.speaker: Sr. Iohn Finch.
sp.p: I had thought Mr. Prynne had had no eares, but me thinkes hee hath eares; which cau≈øed many of the Lords to take the ≈øtricter view of him; and for their better ≈øatisfaction, the V≈øher of the Court was commaunded to turne up his haire, and ≈øhew his eares: upon the ≈øight whereof the Lords were di≈øplea≈øed they had beene formerly no more cut off; and ca≈øt out ≈øome di≈øgracefull words of him.

sp.speaker: M. Prynne
sp.p: To which Mr. Prynne replied; My Lords, there is never a one of your Honours, but would be ≈øorry to have your eares as mine are.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: The Lord Keeper replied againe; In good faith hee is ≈øomewhat ≈øawcy.

sp.speaker: M. Prynne
sp.p: I hope (≈øayd Mr. Prynne) your Honours will not be offended, I pray God give you eares to heare.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: The bu≈øines of the day (≈øayd the Lord Keeper) is to proceed on the Pri≈øoners at the Barr.

sp.speaker: M. Prynne
sp.p: Mr. Prynne then humbly de≈øired the Court to give him leave to make a motion or two, which being graunted, he mooves.

Fir≈øt that their Honours would be plea≈øed to accept of a cro≈ø≈øe Bill again≈øt the Prelates, ≈øigned with their owne hands, being that which ≈øtands with the Iu≈øtice of the Court, which he humbly craved, and ≈øo tendred it.

sp.speaker: L. Keep r.
sp.p: As for your cro≈ø≈øe Bill, it is not the bu≈øines of the day; Hereafter if the Court ≈øhall ≈øee ju≈øt cau≈øe, and that it ≈øavours not of Libelling, we may accept of it; for my part I have not ≈øeene it, but have heard ≈øomewhat of it.

sp.speaker: M. Prynne
sp.p: I hope your Honours will not refu≈øe it, being it is on his Maje≈øties behalfe; wee are his Maje≈øties Subjects, and therefore require the Iu≈øtice of the Court.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: But this is not the bu≈øines of the day.

sp.speaker: M. Prynne
sp.p: Why then, My Lords, I have a ≈øecond motion, which I humbly pray your Honours to graunt; which is, That your Lord≈øhips will be plea≈øed to di≈ømi≈ø≈øe the Prelates, here now ≈øitting from having any voyce in the cen≈øure of this cau≈øe (being generally knowne to be Adver≈øaries) as being no wayes agreeable with equity or rea≈øo ‚Ä¢ , that they who are our Adver≈øaries, ≈øhould be our Iudges: Therefore wee humbly crave they may be expunged out of the Court.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: In good faith its a ≈øweet motion is't not? Herein you are become Libellous. And if you ≈øhould thus Libell all the Lords and Reverend Iudges, as you doe the mo≈øt Reverend Prelates, by this your Plea, you would have none to pa≈ø≈øe ≈øentence upon you for your Libelling, becau≈øe they are parties.

sp.speaker: M. Prynne
sp.p: Vnder correction (My Lord) this doth not hold; your Honour need not putt that for a certainty, which is an uncertainty; wee have nothing to ≈øay to any of your Honours, but onely to the Prelates.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: Well, proceed to the bu≈øines of the day; Read the Information. Which was read, being very large; and the≈øe five Bookes annexed therevnto (viz.) a Booke of Dr. Ba≈øtwicks written in Latin.

The ≈øecond a little Booke, intiteled, Newes from Ip≈øwich. The third intiteled, A Divine Tragedy, recording Gods fearefull judgements on Sabbath breakers. The fourth Mr. Burtons Booke, intiteled, An Apology of an Appeale to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, with two Sermons for God and the King, preached on the fifth of November la≈øt. The fifth and la≈øt Dr. Ba≈øtwickes Letany.
The Kings Coun≈øell (being five) tooke each of them a ≈øeverall Booke, and de≈øcanted there at the Barre upon them according to their plea≈øure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorney.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney began fir≈øt with Dr. Ba≈øtwickes Latin Booke, picking out here and there particular conclu≈øions that be≈øt ≈øerved for his owne ends, (as did all the other Coun≈øell out of the fower other Bookes) to the great abu≈øe of the Authors, as them≈øelves there immediately complained, intreating them to read the foregoing grounds upon which the ≈øayd conclu≈øions depended, without which they could not under≈øtand the true meaning of them.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Next unto the Attorney, Serjeant Whitfeild falls upon Reverend Mr. Burtons Booke, who vented much bitternes again≈øt that unreprooveable Booke (as all that read it with an hone≈øt and orthodox heart may clearely perceive) ≈øwearing, In good faith, My Lords, there is never a page in this Booke, but de≈øerves a heavier and deeper Cen≈øure then this Court can lay upon him.

Next followed A. B. who in like maner de≈øcanted upon the Newes from Ip≈øwich, charging it to be full of pernitious lyes, and e≈øpecially vindicating the honor of Mathew Wren, Bi≈øhop of Norwich, as being a learned pious and Reverend Father of the Church.

sp.speaker: Mr. Littleton.
sp.p:
In the fourth place followes the Kings Solicitor, who acts his part upon the Divine Tragedy; To which part of it, concerning Gods judgements on Sabbath breakers, hee had little to ≈øay, but onely putt it off with a ≈øcoffe, ≈øaying; that they ≈øate in the Seate of God, who judged tho≈øe accidents which fell out upon per≈øons ≈øuddainly ≈øtrooken, to be the judgement of God for Sabbath-breaking, or
words to the like effect: but enlarged him≈øelfe upon that pa≈ø≈øage, which reflected upon that late Reverend (as hee termed him) and learned Profe≈ø≈øor of the Law, and his Maje≈øties faithfull Servant Mr. William Noy, his Maje≈øties late Attorney, who (as hee ≈øaid) was mo≈øt ≈øhamefully abu≈øed by a ≈ølaunder layd upon him; which was, That it ≈øhould be reported, that Gods judgement fell upon him for ≈øo eagerly pro≈øecuting that innocent per≈øon Mr. Prynne; which judgement was this; That he laughing at Mr. Prynne while hee was ≈øuffering upon the Pillory, was ≈øtrooke with an y≈ø≈øue of blood in his privy part, which by all the art of man could never be ≈øtopped unto the day of his death,a. which was ≈øoone after. But the truth of this (My Lords ≈øayth hee) you ≈øhall finde to be as probable as the re≈øt; for wee have here three or fower Gentlemen of good credit and ranke, to te≈øtify upon oath, that hee had that y≈ø≈øue long before; and thereupon made a ≈øhew as if hee would call for them in before the Lords, to witne≈ø≈øe the truth thereof (with the≈øe particular words, Make roome for the Gentlemen to come in there) but no one witne≈ø≈øe was ≈øeene to appeare: Which was a pretty delu≈øion, and worth all your ob≈øervations that read it: And ≈øo concluded (as the re≈øt) that this Booke al≈øo de≈øerved a heavy and deepe Cen≈øure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Harbert.
sp.p: La≈øtly followes Mr. Harbert, who≈øe de≈øcant was upon Dr. Ba≈øtwickes Letanie, picking out one or two pa≈ø≈øages therein, and ≈øo drawing thence his conclu≈øion, that jointly with the re≈øt, it de≈øerved a heavy Cen≈øure.
The Kings Coun≈øell having all ≈øpoken what they could, the Lord Keeper ≈øayd to the Pri≈øoners at the Barre.

sp.speaker: Lord Keeper.
sp.p: You heare Gentlemen wherewith you are charged; and now, lea≈øt you ≈øhould ≈øay you cannot have liberty to ≈øpeake for your ≈øelves, the Court gives you leave to ≈øpeake what you can, with the≈øe conditions:
Fir≈øt, that you ≈øpeake within the bounds of mode≈øty.
Secondly, that your ≈øpeeches be not Libellous.

sp.speaker: Pri≈øoners.
sp.p: They all three an≈øwered, they hoped ≈øo to order their ≈øpeech as to be free from any immode≈øt or Libellous ≈øpeaking.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: Then ≈øpeake a Gods name, and ≈øhew cau≈øe why the Court ≈øhould not proceed in Cen≈øure (as taking the cau≈øe pro confe≈ø≈øo) again≈øt you.

sp.speaker: M. Prynne
sp.p: My honorable good Lord, ≈øuch a day of the moneth there came a Subpoena from your Honours, to enter my appearance in this Court; which being entred, I tooke forth a coppy of the Information, which being taken, I was to draw my An≈øwer, which I endeavoured to doe, but being ≈øhutt up clo≈øe pri≈øoner, I was de≈øerted of all meanes by which I ≈øhould have done it; for I was no ≈øooner ≈øerved with the Subpoena, but I was ≈øhortly after ≈øhutt up clo≈øe pri≈øoner, with a ≈øu≈øpention of pen, inke and paper; which clo≈øe impri≈øonment did eate up ≈øuch a deale of my time, that I was hindred the bringing in of my An≈øwer: You did a≈ø≈øigne me Coun≈øell, t'is true, but they neglected to come to me, and I could not come to them, being under lock and key: Then upon motion in Court, yee gave me liberty to goe to them; but then pre≈øently after that motion (I know not for what cau≈øe, nor upon who≈øe commaund) I was ≈øhutt up againe: And then I could not compell my Coun≈øell to come to me, and my time was ≈øhort, and I had neither pen nor inke, nor Servant to doe any thing for me, for my Servant was then al≈øo kept clo≈øe pri≈øoner under a Pur≈øevants hands; this was to put impo≈ø≈øibilities upon mee. Then upon a ≈øecond motion for pen and inke (which was graunted me) I drew up ≈øome In≈øtructions, and in a fortnight time ≈øent 40 ≈øheetes to my Coun≈øell; ≈øuddainly after I drew up 40 ≈øheetes more, and ≈øent to them; My Lord, I did nothing but by the advi≈øe of my Coun≈øell, by whom I was ruled in the drawing up of all my An≈øwer, and payd him twice for drawing it, and ≈øome of my Coun≈øell would have ≈øet their hands to it. Here is my An≈øwer, I tender it upon my oath, which your Lord≈øhips cannot deny with the Iu≈øtice of the Court.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: Wee can give you a Pre≈øident, that this Court hath proceeded and taken a cau≈øe pro confe≈ø≈øo for not putting in an An≈øwer in ≈øixe dayes; you have had a great deale of favour ≈øhewed in affording you longer time, and therefore the Court is free from all calumny or a≈øper≈øion, for rejecting your An≈øwer not ≈øigned with the Coun≈øells hands.

sp.speaker: M. Prynne
sp.p:
But one word or two, my Lords, I de≈øire your Honours to heare me; I put a ca≈øe in Law, that is often pleaded before your Lord≈øhips, one man is bound to bring in two witne≈ø≈øes; if both or one of them ≈øayle, that hee cannot bring them in, doth the Law (my Lords)
make it the mans act? You a≈ø≈øigned me two Coun≈øellors; one of them fayled, I cannot compell him; here he is now before you, let him ≈øpeake, if I have not u≈øed all my endeavours to have had him ≈øighed it (which my other Coun≈øell would not have done, if this would have ≈øet his hand to it with him) and to have put it in long ≈øince.

sp.speaker: Coun≈øell.
sp.p: My Lord, there was ≈øo long time ≈øpent ere I could doe any thing, after I was a≈ø≈øigned his Coun≈øell; that it was impo≈ø≈øible his An≈øwer could be drawne vp in ≈øo ≈øhort a time as was allotted; for after long expectation, ≈øeeing hee came not to mee, I went to him, where I found him ≈øhut up clo≈øe pri≈øoner, ≈øo that I could not have acce≈ø≈øe to him; Whereupon I motioned to the Lieftenant of the Tower, to have free liberty of ≈øpeech with him concerning his An≈øwer; which being graunted me, I found him very willing and de≈øirous to have it drawne up; whereupon I did moove in this Court for pen and paper; which was graunted, the which he no ≈øooner had gotten, but he ≈øet him≈øelf to draw up In≈øtructions, and in a ≈øhort time, ≈øent me 40 ≈øheetes; and ≈øoone after I received 40 more; but I found the An≈øwer ≈øo long, and of ≈øuch a nature, that I dur≈øt not ≈øet my hand to it, for feare of giving your Honours di≈øtate.

sp.speaker: M. Prynne
sp.p: My Lords, I did nothing but according to the direction of my Coun≈øell, onely I ≈øpake mine owne words, my An≈øwer was drawne up by his con≈øent, it was his owne act, and hee did approove of it; and if he will be ≈øo ba≈øe a Coward, to doe that in private, which hee dares not acknowledge in publick, I will not let ≈øuch a ≈øinne lye on my con≈øcience, let it re≈øt with him. Here is my An≈øwer, which though it be not ≈øigned with their hands, yet here I tender it upon my oath, which you cannot in Ju≈øtice deny.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: But Mr. Prynne the Court de≈øires no ≈øuch long An≈øwer; Are you guilty or not guilty?

sp.speaker: M. Prynne
sp.p:
My good Lord, I am to an≈øwer in a defen≈øive way, Is here any one, that can witnes any thing again≈øt me? Let him come in. The Law of God ≈øtandeth thus; That a man is not to be condemned, but under the mouth of two or three witne≈ø≈øes. Here is no witnes comes in again≈øt me, my Lord, neither is there in all the Information one clau≈øe that doth particularly fall on mee, but onely in the generall, there is no Booke layd to my charge. And ≈øhall I be condemned
for a particular act, when no accu≈øation of any particular act can be brought again≈øt mee? This were mo≈øt unju≈øt and wicked. Here I tender my An≈øwer to the Information upon my oath; My Lord, you did impo≈øe impo≈ø≈øibilities upon me, I could doe no more then I was able.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: Well hold your peace, your An≈øwer comes too late. Speake you Dr. Ba≈øtwicke.

sp.speaker: Dr. Bastwicke.
sp.p:
My Honorable Lords, me thinks you looke like an A≈ø≈øembly of Gods, and ≈øit in the place of God; yee are called the Sonnes of God: And ≈øince I have compared you to Gods, give me leave a little to paralell the one with the other, to ≈øee whither the compari≈øon betweene God and you doth hold in this noble and righteous cau≈øe. This was the carriage of Almighty God in the cau≈øe of Sodome: Before hee would pronounce ≈øentence, or execute judgement, hee would fir≈øt come downe, and ≈øee whither the crime was altogether according to the cry that was come up. And with whom doth the Lord con≈øult, when hee came downe? with his Servant Abraham, and hee gives the rea≈øon; for I know (≈øayth hee) that Abraham will commaund his children and hou≈øehold after him, that they ≈øhall keep the way of the Lord to doe Iu≈øtice and Iudgement. My good Lords, thus ≈øtands the ca≈øe betweene your Honours and us this day; There is a great cry come up into your eares, again≈øt us, from the Kings Attorney; why now be you plea≈øed to de≈øcend and ≈øee if the crime be according to the cry, and con≈øult (with God) (not the Prelates being the adver≈øary part, and (as it is apparant to all the World) doe proudly ≈øet them≈øelves again≈øt the wayes of God, and from whom none can expect Iu≈øtice or Iudgement) but with righteous men, that will be impartiall on either ≈øide, before you proceed to Cen≈øure, which Cen≈øure you cannot pa≈ø≈øe on us, without great inju≈øtice before you heare our An≈øwers read: Here is my An≈øwer, which I here tender upon my oath; My good Lords, give us leave to ≈øpeake in our owne defence; wee are not con≈øcious to our ≈øelves of any thing wee have done that de≈øerves a Cen≈øure this day in this Honourable Court, but that wee have ever laboured to maintaine the Honor, Dignity, and Prerogative Royall of our Soveraigne Lord the King, Let my Lord the King live forever. Had I a thou≈øand lives, I ≈øhould thinke them all too little to ≈øpend for the
maintenance of his Maje≈øties Royall Prerogative, My good Lords, can you proceed to Cen≈øure before you know my cau≈øe? I dare undertake, that ≈øcarce any one of your Lord≈øhips have read my Bookes; And can you then Cen≈øure me for what you know not, and before I have made my defence? O my Noble Lords! Is this righteous Iudgement? This were again≈øt the Law of God and man, to condemne a man, before you know his crime. The Governour before whom S. Paul was carried (who was a very Heathen) would fir≈øt heare his cau≈øe before he would pa≈ø≈øe any Cen≈øure upon him; And doth it be≈øeeme ≈øo Noble and Chri≈øtian A≈ø≈øembly to condemne me before my An≈øwer be peru≈øed and my cau≈øe knowne? Men, Brethren, and Fathers, into what an age are wee fallen? I de≈øire your Honours to lay a≈øide your Cen≈øure for this day, and inquire into my cau≈øe, heare my An≈øwer read; which if you refu≈øe to doe, I here profe≈ø≈øe, I will cloath it in Roman Buffe, and ≈øend it abroad unto the view of all the World, to cleare mine innocency, and ≈øee your great inju≈øtice in this cau≈øe.

sp.speaker: Lord Keeper.
sp.p: But this is not the bu≈øines of the day; Why brought you not in your An≈øwer in due time?

sp.speaker: Dr. Ba≈øtwicke.
sp.p: My Lord, a long time ≈øince I tendred it to your Honour, I ≈øayled not in any one particular: And if my Coun≈øell be ≈øo ba≈øe and cowardly, that they dare not ≈øigne it for feare of the Prelates (as I can make it appeare) therefore have I no An≈øwer? My Lord, here is my An≈øwer, which though my Coun≈øell out of a ba≈øe ≈øpirit dare not ≈øet their hands unto, yet I tender it upon my oath.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: But Mr. Dr. you ≈øhould have beene briefe; you tendred in too large an An≈øwer, which (as I heard) is as Libellous as your Bookes.

sp.speaker: Dr. Ba≈øtw.
sp.p: No, my Lord, it is not Libellous though large, I have none to an≈øwer for me but my ≈øelfe, and being left to my ≈øelfe, I mu≈øt plead my con≈øcience in an≈øwer to every circum≈øtance of the Information.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: What ≈øay you Mr. D. are you guilty, or not guilty? An≈øwer aye or no, you needed not to have troubled your ≈øelf ≈øo much about ≈øo large an An≈øwer.

sp.speaker: Dr. Bastwicke.
sp.p: I know, none of your Honours have read my Bookes; And can you with the Iu≈øtice of the Court, condemne me before you know what is written in my Bookes?

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: What ≈øay you to that was read to you even now?

sp.speaker: Dr. Ba≈øtw.
sp.p: My Lord, He that read it did ≈øo murther the ≈øence of it, that had I not knowne, what I had written, I could not tell what to have made of it.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: What ≈øay you to the other Sentence read to you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Ba≈øtw.
sp.p: That was none of mine, I will not father that which was none of my owne.

sp.speaker: L. Dor≈øeit.
sp.p: Did not you ≈øend that Booke, as now it is, to a Noble mans hou≈øe, together with a Letter directed to him?

sp.speaker: D. Ba≈øtw.
sp.p: Yea, my Lord, I did ≈øo, but withall you may ≈øee in my Epi≈øtle ≈øet before the Booke, I did at fir≈øt di≈øclayme what was not mine; I ≈øent my Booke over by a Dutch Merchant, who it was that wrote the addition I doe not know, but my Epi≈øtle ≈øet to my Booke, made manife≈øt what was mine, and what was not; and I cannot ju≈øtly ≈øuffer for what was none of mine.

sp.speaker: L. Arund.
sp.p: My Lord, you heare by his owne ≈øpeech, the cau≈øe is taken pro confe≈ø≈øo.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: Yea, you ≈øay true my Lord.

sp.speaker: Dr. Bastw.
sp.p: My noble Lord of Arundell, I know you are a noble Prince in I≈ørael, and a great Peere of this Realme; There are ≈øome honorable Lords in this Court, that have beene forced out as combatants in a ≈øingle duell; it is betweene the Prelates and us, at this time as betweene two that have appointed the feild. The one being a coward goes to the Magi≈øtrate, and by vertue of his Authority di≈øarmes the other of his weapons, and gives him a Bullru≈øh, and then challenges him to fight. If this be not ba≈øe cowardice, I know not what belongs to a Souldier. This is the ca≈øe betweene the Prelates and us, they take away our weapons (our An≈øwers) by vertue of your Authority, by which we ≈øhould defend our ≈øelves, and yet they bidd us fight. My Lord, doth not this favour of a ba≈øe cowardly ≈øpirit? I know, my Lord, there is a Decree gonne forth (for my Sentence was pa≈ø≈øed long ≈øince) to cut of our eares.

sp.speaker: Lord Keeper.
sp.p: Who ≈øhall know our Cen≈øure, before the Court pa≈ø≈øe it? Doe you prophe≈øy of your ≈øelves?

sp.speaker: Dr. Bastw.
sp.p:
My Lord, I am able to proove it, and that from the mouth of the Prelates owne Servants, that in Augu≈øt la≈øt it was decreed, that Dr. Ba≈øtwicke ≈øhould loo≈øe his eares. O my Noble Lords! Is this righteous judgement? I may ≈øay, as the Apo≈øtle once ≈øayd, What, whipp a Roman? I have beene a Souldier able to lead an Army into the field, to fight valiantly for the honour of their Prince; Now I am a Phy≈øitian, able to cure Nobles, Kings, Princes and Emperors: And to curtolize a Romans eares, like a Curre, O my honorable Lords! is it not too ba≈øe an act for ≈øo noble an a≈ø≈øembly, and for ≈øo righteous and honorable a cau≈øe? The cau≈øe my Lords is great, it concernes the glory of God, the honour of our King, who≈øe Prerogative wee labour to maintaine and to ≈øet up in a high maner, in which your Honours Liberties are engaged: And doth not ≈øuch a cau≈øe de≈øerve your Lord≈øhips con≈øideration, before you proceed to Cen≈øure? Your Honours may be plea≈øed to con≈øider, that in the la≈øt cau≈øe heard and cen≈øured in this Court, betweene St. Iames Bagge and the Lord Moone, wherein your Lord≈øhips tooke a great deale of paynes, with a great deale of patience, to heare the Bills on both ≈øides, with all the An≈øwers and Depo≈øitions largely layd open before you; which cau≈øe when you had fully heard, ≈øome of your Honours, now ≈øitting in Court, ≈øayd, You could not in con≈øcience proceed to Cen≈øure, till you had taken ≈øome time to recollect your ≈øelves: If in a cau≈øe of that nature, you could ≈øpend ≈øo much time, and afterwards recollect your ≈øelves before you would pa≈ø≈øe Cen≈øure: How much more ≈øhould it moove your Honours, to take ≈øome time in a cau≈øe wherein the glory of God, the Prerogative of his Maje≈øtie, your Honours dignity, and the Subjects Liberty is ≈øo largely ingaged? My good Lords, it may fall out to be any of your Lord≈øhips ca≈øes to ≈øtand as Delinquents at this Barre, as wee now doe: It is not unknowne to your Honours, the next cau≈øe that is to ≈øucceed ours, is touching a per≈øon that ≈øometimes hath beene in greate≈øt power in this Court: And if the mutations and revolutions of per≈øons and times be ≈øuch, then I doe mo≈øt humbly be≈øeech your Honours to looke on us, as it may befall your ≈øelves. But if all this will not prevaile with your Honours, to peru≈øe my Bookes, and
heare my An≈øwer, read, which here I tender upon the word and oath of a Soldier, a Gentleman, a Scholler, and a Phy≈øitian: I will cloath them (as I ≈øayd before) in Roman Buffe, and di≈øper≈øe them throughout the Chri≈øtian world, that future generations may ≈øee the Innocency of this cau≈øe, and your Honors unju≈øt proceedings in it; all which I will doe, though it co≈øt me my life.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: Mr. Dr. I thought you would be angry.

sp.speaker: Dr. Ba≈øtw.
sp.p: No my Lord, you are mis-taken, I am not angry nor pa≈ø≈øionate, all that I doe pre≈ø≈øe is, that you would be plea≈øed to peru≈øe my An≈øwer.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: Well, hold your peace. Mr. Burton, what ≈øay you?

sp.speaker: M. Burton.
sp.p: My good Lords, your Honors (it ≈øhould ≈øeeme) doe determine to Cen≈øure us, and take our cau≈øe pro confe≈ø≈øo, although we have laboured to give your Honors ≈øatisfaction in all things: My Lords, what you have to ≈øay again≈øt my Booke, I confe≈ø≈øe I did write it, yet did I not any thing out of intent of Commotion or Sedition: I delivered nothing, but what my Text ledd me too, being cho≈øen to ≈øuite with the day, namely the fifth of November; the words were the≈øe, &c.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: Mr. Burton, I pray ≈øtand not naming Texts of Scripture now, we doe not ≈øend for you to preach, but to an≈øwer to tho≈øe things that are objected again≈øt you.

sp.speaker: M. Burton.
sp.p: My Lord, I have drawne up my An≈øwer to my great paynes and charges, which An≈øwer was ≈øigned with my Coun≈øells hands, and received into the Court, according to the Rule and Order thereof. And I did not thinke to have beene called this day to a Cen≈øure, but have had a legall proceeding by way of Bill and An≈øwer.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: Your An≈øwer was impertinent.

sp.speaker: M. Burton
sp.p: My An≈øwer (after it was entred into the Court) was referred to the Iudges, but by what meanes I doe not know, whither it be impertinent, and what cau≈øe your Lord≈øhips had to ca≈øt it out, I know not. But after it was approoved of, and received, it was ca≈øt out as an impertinent An≈øwer.

sp.speaker: L. Finch.
sp.p: The Iudges did you a good turne to make it impertinent, for it was as Libellous as your Booke, ≈øo that your An≈øwer de≈øerved a Cen≈øure alone.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: What ≈øay you Mr. Burton, are you guilty, or not?

sp.speaker: M. Burton
sp.p: My Lord, I de≈øire you not onely to peru≈øe my Booke, here and there, but every pa≈ø≈øage of it.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: Mr. Burton, time is ≈øhort, are you guilty, or not guilty? What ≈øay you to that which was read? Doth it become a Mini≈øter to deliver him≈øelf in ≈øuch a rayling and ≈øcandalous way?

sp.speaker: M. Burton
sp.p: In my judgement, and as I can proove it, it was neither rayling nor ≈øcandalous; I conceive that a Mini≈øter hath a larger liberty then alwayes to goe in a milde ≈øtrayne: I being the Pa≈øtor of my people, whom I had in charge, and was to in≈øtruct, I ≈øuppo≈øed it was my duety to informe them of tho≈øe Innovations that are crept into the Church, as likewi≈øe of the danger and ill con≈øequence of them: As for my An≈øwer, yee blotted out what yee would, and then the re≈øt which made be≈øt for your owne ends, you would have to ≈øtand: And now for mee to tender onely what will ≈øerve for your owne turnes, and renounce the re≈øt, were to de≈øert my cau≈øe, which before I will doe, or de≈øert my con≈øcience, I will rather de≈øert my body, and deliver it up to your Lord≈øhips to doe with it, what you will.

sp.speaker: L. Keeper.
sp.p: This is a place, where you ≈øhould crave mercy and favour, Mr. Burton, and not ≈øtand upon ≈øuch termes as you doe.

sp.speaker: M. Burton
sp.p: There wherein I have offended through humane frailty, I crave of God and man pardon: And I pray God, that in your Sentence, you may ≈øo Cen≈øure us, that you may not ≈øinne again≈øt the Lord.

div.p: Then the Pri≈øoners de≈øiring to ≈øpeake a little more for them≈øelves, were commaunded to ≈øilence. And ≈øo the Lords proceeded to Cen≈øure.

div.head: The Lord Cottingtons Cen≈øure.
div.p: I Condemne the≈øe three men to loo≈øe their eares in the Pallace-yard at We≈øtmin≈øter; To be fined five thou≈øand pounds a man to his Maje≈øtie: And to perpetuall impri≈øonment in three remote places of the Kingdome, namely, the Ca≈øtles of Carnaruan, Cornwall, and Lanca≈øter.

div.p: THe Execution of the Lods Cen≈øure in Starre-Chamber upon Dr. Ba≈øtwicke, Mr. Prynne, and Mr. Burton, in the Pallace-yard at We≈øtmin≈øter, the 30th. day of Iune la≈øt 1637. at the ≈øpectation whereof the number of people was ≈øo great (the place being very large) that it cau≈øed admirat ‚Ä¢ on in all that beheld them; who came with tender affections to behold tho≈øe three renowned Souldiers and Servants of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who came with mo≈øt undaunted and magnanimous courage thereunto, having their way ≈øtrawed with ≈øweet hearbes from the hou≈øe out of which they came to the Pillary, with all the honour that could be done unto them.

Dr. Ba≈øtwicke and Mr. Burton fir≈øt meeting, they did clo≈øe one in the others armes three times, with as much expre≈ø≈øions of love as might be, rejoycing that they mett at ≈øuch a place, upon ≈øuch an occa≈øion, and that God had ≈øo highly honoured them, as to call them forth to ≈øuffer for his glorious Truth.

Then immediately after, Mr. Prynne camme, the Dr. and hee ≈øaluting each other, as Mr. Burton and hee did before. The Dr. then went up fir≈øt on the Scaffold, and his wife immediately following came up to him, and like a loving Spou≈øe ≈øaluted each eare with a ki≈ø≈øe, and then his mouth; who≈øe tender love, boldnes, and cheerefullnes ≈øo wrought upon the peoples affections, that they gave a marvailous great ≈øhowte, for joy to behold it. Her hu≈øband de≈øired her not to be in the lea≈øt maner di≈ømay'd at his ≈øuffrings: And ≈øo for a while they parted, ≈øhe u≈øing the≈øe words: Farewell my Deere≈øt, be of good comfort, I am nothing di≈ømay'd. And then the Dr. began to ≈øpeake the≈øe words.

There are many that are this day Spectators of our ≈øtanding here,Dr. Bastwicke. as Delinquents, though not Delinquents, we ble≈ø≈øe God for it. I am not con≈øcious to my ≈øelf wherein I have committed the lea≈øt tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe (to take this outward ≈øhame) either again≈øt my God, or my King. And I doe the rather ≈øpeake it, that you that are now beholders, may take notice, how farre Innocency will pre≈øerve you in ≈øuch a day as this is; for wee come here in the ≈øtrength of our God, who hath mightily ≈øupported us, and filled our hearts with greater comfort then our ≈øhame or contempt can be. The fir≈øt occa≈øion
of my trouble was by the Prelates, for writing a Booke again≈øt the Pope, and the Pope of Canterbury ≈øayd I wrote again≈øt him, and therefore que≈øtioned mee: But if the Pre≈ø≈øes were as open to us, as formerly they have beene, we would ≈øhatter his Kingdome about his eares: But be yee not deterred by their power, neither be affrighted at our ≈øufferings; Let none determine to turne from the wayes of the Lord, but goe on, fight couragiou≈øly again≈øt Gog and Magog. I know there be many here who have ≈øet many dayes apart for our behalfe, (let the Prelates take notice of it) and they have ≈øent up ≈øtrong prayers to heaven for us, wee feele the ≈øtrength and benefit of them at this time; I would have you to take notice of it; wee have felt the ≈øtrength and benefit of your prayers all along this cau≈øe. In a word, ≈øo farre I am from ba≈øe feare, or caring for any thing they can doe, or ca≈øt upon mee, that had I as much blood as would ≈øwell the Theames, I would ≈øhedd it every droppe in this cau≈øe. Therefore be not any of you di≈øcouraged, be not daunted at their power, ever labouring to pre≈øerve Innocency, and keep peace within, goe on in the ≈øtrength of your God, and he will never fayle you, in ≈øuch a day as this; As I ≈øayd before, ≈øo I ≈øay againe; Had I as many lives as I have heires on my head, or dropps of blood in my veynes, I would give them up all for this cau≈øe. This plot of ≈øending vs to tho≈øe remote places, was fir≈øt con≈øulted and agitated by the Ie≈øuites, as I can make it plainely appeare. O ≈øee what times wee are fallen into, that the Lords mu≈øt ≈øit to act the Ie≈øuites plots! For our owne parts wee owe no malice to the per≈øons of any of the Prelates, but would lay our necks under their feet to doe them good as they are men, but again≈øt the u≈øurpation of their power, as they are Bi≈øhops, wee doe profe≈ø≈øe our ≈øelves enemies till doomes day.
Mr. Prynne ≈øhaking the Dr. by the hand, de≈øired him that hee might ≈øpeake a word or two. With all my heart, ≈øayd the Doctor.

The cau≈øe (≈øayd Mr. Prynne) of my ≈øtanding here,M. Prynne is for not bringing in my An≈øwer, for which my cau≈øe is taken pro confe≈ø≈øo again≈øt mee. What endeavours I u≈øed for the bringing in thereof, that, God and my owne con≈øcience, and my Coun≈øell knowes, who≈øe cowardi≈øe ≈øtands upon Record to all ages. For rather then I will have my cau≈øe a leading cau≈øe, to deprive the Subjects of that
liberty which I ≈øeeke to maintaine, I rather expo≈øe my per≈øon to a leading example, to beare this puni≈øhment: And I be≈øeech you all to take notice of their proceedings in this cau≈øe. When I was ≈øerved with a Subpoena into this Court, I was ≈øhut up clo≈øe pri≈øoner, that I could have no acce≈ø≈øe to Coun≈øell, nor admitted pen, inke or paper to draw up my An≈øwer by my In≈øtructions, for which I feed them twice (though to no purpo≈øe) yet when all was done, my An≈øwer would not be accepted into the Court, though I tendered it upon my oath. I appeale to all the world, if this were a legall or ju≈øt proceeding. Our accu≈øation is in point of Libell (but ≈øuppo≈øedly) again≈øt the Prelates. To cleare this now I will give you a little light, what the Law is in point of Libell (of which profe≈ø≈øion I have ≈øometimes beene, and ≈øtill profe≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe to have ≈øome knowledge in) you ≈øhall finde in ca≈øe of Libell, two Statutes: The one in the ≈øecond of Queen Mary; The other in the ≈øeaventh of Queen Elizabeth. That in the ≈øecond of Queen Mary, the extremity and heighth of it runs thus: That if a Libeller doth goe ≈øo farre and ≈øo high as to Libell again≈øt King or Queen by denomination, the higth and extremity of the Law is; that they lay no greater fine on him then an hundred pounds, with a moneths impri≈øonment; and no corporall puni≈øhment, except he doe refu≈øe to pay his fine; and then to inflict ≈øome puni≈øhment in liewe of that fine at the moneths end: Neither was this Cen≈øure to be pa≈ø≈øed on him, except it were fully prooved by two witne≈ø≈øes, who were to produce a certificat of their good demeanor for the credit of their report, or el≈øe confe≈ø≈øed by the Libeller. You ≈øhall finde in that Statute 7. Eliz. ≈øome further addition to the former of 2. Mariae, and that onely in point of fine and puni≈øhment; and it mu≈øt ≈øtill reach as high as the per≈øon of King and Queen. Here this Statute doth ≈øet a fine of two hundred pounds; the other, but one: This ≈øets three moneths impri≈øonment; the former but one: So that therein onely they differ. But in this they both agree, namely, at the end of his impri≈øonment to pay his fine, and ≈øo to goe free without any further que≈øtioning: But if hee refu≈øe to pay his fine, then the Court is to inflict ≈øome puni≈øhment on him corre≈øpondent to his fine. Now ≈øee the di≈øparity betweene tho≈øe times of theirs, and ours. A Libeller in Queen Maries time was fined but an hundred pounds, in Queen Elizabeths time two
hundred: In Queen Maries dayes but a moneths impri≈øonment; in Queen Elizabeths three moneths; and not ≈øo great a fine, if they libelled not again≈øt King or Queen. Formerly the greate≈øt fine was but two hundred pounds, though again≈øt King or Queen; Now five thou≈øand pounds, though but again≈øt the Prelates, and that but ≈øuppo≈øedly, which cannot be prooved: Formerly, but three moneths impri≈øonment; Now perpetuall impri≈øonment: Then, upon paying the fine, no corporall puni≈øhment was to be inflicted: But now, infamous puni≈øhment with the lo≈ø≈øe of blood and all other circum≈øtances that may aggravate it. See now what times wee are fallen into, when that Libelling (if it were ≈øo) again≈øt Prelates onely, ≈øhall fall higher, then if it touched Kings and Princes.

That which I have to ≈øpeake of next, is this: The Prelates find them≈øelves exceedingly agrieved and vexed again≈øt what wee have written concerning the u≈øurpation of their calling, where indeed wee declare their calling not to be Jure Divino. I make no doubt, but there are ≈øome Intelligencers or Abbettors within the hearing, whom I would have well to know and take notice of what I now ≈øay. I here in this place make this offer to them, That if I may be admitted a fayre di≈øpute, on fayre termes, for my cau≈øe; that I will maintaine, and doe here make the challenge again≈øt all the Prelates in the Kings Dominions, and again≈øt all the Prelates in Chri≈øtendome, (let them take in the Pope, and all to help them) that their calling is not Iure Divino. I will ≈øpeake it againe; I make the challeng again≈øt all the Prelates in the Kings Dominions, and all Chri≈øtendome to maintaine, that their calling is not Iure Divino. If I make it not good, let me be hanged up at the Hall-Gate: Whereupon the people gave a great ≈øhout.

The next thing that I am to ≈øpeake of, is this: The Prelates find them≈øelves exceedingly agrieved and vext again≈øt what I have written in point of Law, concerning their Writs and Proces, That the ≈øending forth of Writs and Proces in their owne name, is again≈øt all Law and Iu≈øtice, and doth entrench on his Maje≈øties Prerogative Royall, and the Subjects Liberties. And here now I make a ≈øecond challeng again≈øt all the Lawyers in the Kingdome in way of fayre Di≈øpute, That I will maintaine, the Prelates ≈øending forth of Writs and Proces in their owne names, to be again≈øt all
Law and Iu≈øtice, and entrencheth on his Maje≈øties Prerogative Royall, and the Subjects Liberty. Lea≈øt it ≈øhould be forgotten, I ≈øpeake it againe, I here challeng all the whole Society of the Law upon a fayre Di≈øpute to maintaine, That the ≈øending forth of Writs and Proces in the Prelates owne names, to be again≈øt all Law and Iu≈øtice, and entrencheth on the Kings Prerogative Royall, and the Subjects Liberty. If I be not able to make it good, let me be put to the tormentinge≈øt death they can devi≈øe.

Wee pray≈øe the Lord, wee feare none but God and the King: Had wee re≈øpected our Liberties, wee had not ≈øtood here at this time: it was for the generall good and Liberties of you all that wee have now thus farre engaged our owne Liberties in this cau≈øe. For did you know, how deepely they have entrenched on your Liberties in point of Popery; If you knew but into what times you are ca≈øt, it would make you looke about you: And if you did but ≈øee what changes and revolutions of per≈øons, cau≈øes and actions, have beene made by one man, you would more narrowly looke into your Previledges, and ≈øee how farre your Liberty did lawfully extend, and ≈øo maintaine it.

This is the ≈øecond time that I have beene brought to this place, who hath beene the Author of it, I thinke you all well know: For the fir≈øt time, If I could have had leave given me, I could ea≈øily have cleered my ≈øelf of that which was then layd to my charge: As al≈øo I could have done now, if I might have beene permitted to ≈øpeake, That Booke for which I ≈øuffered formerly, e≈øpecially for ≈øome particular words therein written, which I quoted out of Gods Word and auncient Fathers, for which notwith≈øtanding, they pa≈ø≈øed Cen≈øure on me; That ≈øame Booke was twice licen≈øed by publike Authority, and the ≈øame words I then ≈øuffered for, they are againe made u≈øe of, and applyed in the ≈øame ≈øence by Heylin in his Booke lately printed, and dedicated to the King, and no exceptions taken again≈øt them, but are very well taken.

Aye (≈øayd Dr. Ba≈øtwicke) and there is another Booke of his licen≈øed, wherein hee rayles again≈øt us three at his plea≈øure;Dr. Ba≈øtwicke. and again≈øt all the Martyrs that ≈øuffered in Queen Maries dayes, calling them Schi≈ømaticall Hereticks. And there is another Booke of Pocklingtons licen≈øed; they be as full of lyes, as doggs be full of fleas; but were the Pre≈ø≈øes as open to us, as they are to them, wee would pay them and their great Ma≈øter that upholds them, and charge them with notorious Bla≈øphemy.

Sayd Mr. Prynne, You all at this pre≈øent ≈øee,M. Prynne there be no degrees of men exempted from ≈øuffering: Here is a Reverend Divine for the Soule, a Phy≈øitian for the Body, and a Lawyer for the E≈øtate: I had thought they would have let alone their owne Society, and not have medled with any of them. And the next (for ought I know) may be a Bi≈øhop. You ≈øee they ≈øpare none of what ≈øociety or calling ≈øoever, none are exempted that cro≈ø≈øe their owne ends. Gentlemen, looke to your ≈øelves; If all the Martyrs that ≈øuffered in Queen Maries dayes, are accounted and called Schi≈ømaticall Hereticks and Factious Fellowes: What ≈øhall wee looke for? div.p: THE night before his ≈øuffering, about eight a clocke, when he fir≈øt had certaine notice thereof, upon occa≈øion of his wives going to a≈øke the Warden, whither her hu≈øband ≈øhould ≈øuffer the next day, immediately he felt his ≈øpirits to be ray≈øed to a farre higher pitch of re≈øolution and courage to undergoe his ≈øufferings, then formerly he did, ≈øo as hee intreated the Lord to hold up his ≈øpirits at that heigth all the next day in his ≈øufferings, that hee might not flagg nor faint, lea≈øt any di≈øhonour might come to his Maje≈øtie or the cau≈øe: And the Lord heard him: For all the next day in his ≈øuffering (both before and after) his ≈øpirits were carried aloft as it were upon Eagles wings (as him≈øelf ≈øayd) farre aboue all apprehen≈øion of ≈øhame or paine.

After a while, hee having a No≈øegay in his hand, a Bee came and pitched on the No≈øegay, and began to ≈øuck the flowers very ≈øavourly, which hee beholding and well ob≈øerving, ≈øayd, Doe yee not ≈øee this poore Bee?
